{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3497706,"name":"Michael Tucker","username":"mtuckerFRC4381","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T11:47:09.662Z","cooked":"

We at Gull Lake Area Robotics in Richland MI have conjured up a 54A external load that can run in parallel with the West Mountain Radio Computer Battery Analyzer. The box we built has a composite 60A test load, costs less than $225.00, and reduces the 75-minute test cycle to less than 15 minutes.

Everyone struggles with battery confidence. We are sharing this work because we believe this can benefit other teams.

We went through five design iterations on our journey to the production result. The 11-page PDF can be viewed and downloaded at this link.

Cheers everyone, and here’s to a great Reefscape season!

Mike T, Electrical Sub-Team Mentor
4381 - Twisted Devils
4422 - Twisted Angels

This is fantastic! We even discussed getting a second tester due to the time investment for testing batteries. With 20 new batteries each season (2 teams) and selectively testing previous season batteries, it takes almost the entire off-season to get it done.
I know what my electrical subteam is doing next week…lol.
Thank you for the comprehensive write-up!

In the V5 section of your document, it states “Increase the CBA current test to 5.4A to obtain the 60A load.” Does the CBA still measure 5.4A even though the total load current is 60A? Do you scale the mAh measurement from the CBA to account for the current flowing through the external resistors?

In the write-up, they mentioned filling them with solder.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T19:08:12.675Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":54,"readers_count":53,"score":10.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484456,"topic_slug":"amp-up-your-battery-testing-at-a-reasonable-cost","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":63541,"username":"Jwal","name":"Joseph Walters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44484,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/amp-up-your-battery-testing-at-a-reasonable-cost/484456/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503247,"name":"Michael Tucker","username":"mtuckerFRC4381","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T19:41:04.920Z","cooked":"

I potted solder into the 4 AWG terminals with a 50% fill, then I inserted the wires and let everything cool to a solid state. I did that for the 1/4" lugs on the Main breaker and the Anderson SB120 terminals.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T19:41:04.920Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":51,"readers_count":50,"score":10.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":484456,"topic_slug":"amp-up-your-battery-testing-at-a-reasonable-cost","display_username":"Michael Tucker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63541,"username":"Jwal","name":"Joseph Walters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39901,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Electronics Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/amp-up-your-battery-testing-at-a-reasonable-cost/484456/12","custom_user_title":"Electronics Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503254,"name":"Michael Tucker","username":"mtuckerFRC4381","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T19:44:35.166Z","cooked":"

Yes, and No. Yes, the 9 2 Ohm resistors in parallel create a composite 54 Amp load. No in that the CBA doesn’t know about the external load.

The two fans carry a 0.2 amp load each as does the automotive relay.

In order to use the CBA with this there has to have some sort of internal current draw at this device. 5.4A plus 0.6 A plus 54 Amps gets everything rounded up to 60A.

Elaborating here.
The CBA only knows it’s testing a battery at 5.4A. It’s a parallel device connected to the 54A load amplifier. As such, you can’t rely on the right side table that calculates the battery capacity.

Instead, what you are looking for in the graph is a battery that can sustain a 60A draw for at least 7 minutes.

This and with consideration of the measured battery internal resistance being under 0.019 Ohms, is what I would rate as a competition ready battery.
